question.title: How to reduce the height of a JPanel used as a header in Java Swing?
question.body:
I’m building a simple Java Swing UI and want a thin red header bar at the top with just a title label (“Unit Converter”).

However, the JPanel takes up too much vertical space. I only want a slim horizontal strip. I’m using a GridLayout(3, 0) on the frame and adding three panels (header, content, footer).

Here’s the relevant part:

import javax.swing.*;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        ConverterView view = new ConverterView();
    }

}

public enum Units {
    METRE, CENTIMETRE, DECIMETRE, KILOMETRE
}

public enum UnitCategory {
    LENGTH, WEIGHT, TEMPERATURE, TIME, VOLUME, AREA, SPEED, ENERGY
}

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;

public class ConverterView {

    private JLabel titleLabel;
    private JLabel categoryLabel;
    private JLabel categoryUnit;
    private JLabel inputUnitLabel;
    private JLabel outputUnitLabel;
    private JLabel outcomeLabel;
    private JLabel valueLabel;
    private JComboBox<UnitCategory> categoryBox;
    private JComboBox<Units> inputBoxUnit;
    private JComboBox<Units> outputBoxUnit;
    private JTextField sourceValue;
    private JTextField targetValue;
    private JButton convertButton;
    private JPanel upperPanel;
    private JPanel middlePanel;
    private JPanel lowerPanel;
    private JFrame frame;
    private JLabel resultLabel;
    private JTextField resultTextField;

    public ConverterView() {
        createComponents();
        layoutComponents();

        frame.pack();
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    private void createComponents() {

        titleLabel = new JLabel("Unit Converter");
        titleLabel.setFont(new Font("Calibri", Font.BOLD, 20));

        frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(350, 350));
        frame.setLayout(new GridLayout(3, 0));
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);

        categoryLabel = new JLabel("Category");
        inputUnitLabel = new JLabel("Input Unit");
        outputUnitLabel = new JLabel("Output Unit");
        valueLabel = new JLabel("Value");
        outcomeLabel = new JLabel("Outcome");
        resultLabel = new JLabel("Result");
        resultTextField = new JTextField();

        convertButton = new JButton("Convert");
        convertButton.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(250, 30));

        inputBoxUnit = new JComboBox<>(Units.values());
        outputBoxUnit = new JComboBox<>(Units.values());
        categoryBox = new JComboBox<>(UnitCategory.values());

        upperPanel = new JPanel();
        upperPanel.setBackground(Color.red);
        upperPanel.setLayout(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));

        middlePanel = new JPanel();
        middlePanel.setBackground(Color.yellow);
        middlePanel.setLayout(new GridLayout(3, 2));

        lowerPanel = new JPanel();
        lowerPanel.setBackground(Color.blue);
        lowerPanel.setLayout(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));
    }

    private void layoutComponents() {

        upperPanel.add(titleLabel);

        middlePanel.add(categoryLabel);
        middlePanel.add(categoryBox);
        middlePanel.add(inputUnitLabel);
        middlePanel.add(inputBoxUnit);
        middlePanel.add(valueLabel);
        middlePanel.add(resultLabel);
        middlePanel.add(resultTextField);
        lowerPanel.add(convertButton);

        frame.add(upperPanel);
        frame.add(middlePanel);
        frame.add(lowerPanel);
    }

}

Is there a way to limit the height of upperPanel so it just fits the title label and doesn’t stretch?

answers.body:
Problem Recap

  • GridLayout(3, 0) splits the frame into 3 equal-height rows.

  • Your slim header (upperPanel) is stretched to 1/3 of the frame height, which is much taller than the label needs.

Solutions

1. Use BorderLayout Instead of GridLayout

BorderLayout allows you to put your header in the NORTH region, which will only be as tall as its preferred height (the label). The content can go in CENTER, and the footer in SOUTH.

How to do it:
Replace:

frame.setLayout(new GridLayout(3, 0));

With:

frame.setLayout(new BorderLayout());

Then, add your panels like this:

frame.add(upperPanel, BorderLayout.NORTH);

frame.add(middlePanel, BorderLayout.CENTER);

frame.add(lowerPanel, BorderLayout.SOUTH);

Result:

  • The header (upperPanel) will be only as tall as needed for the label.

  • The footer will also be compact.

  • The content panel (middlePanel) will take the remaining space.

2. If You Must Use GridLayout: Set Fixed Height for Header Panel

If you need to use GridLayout, you can set the preferred size of the header panel, but GridLayout ignores preferred heights and still stretches panels equally.
Workarounds:

  • Use a different layout (see above).

  • Or, nest the header panel in another panel with a fixed height, but this is hacky and not recommended.

3. Set Minimum/Preferred Size on the Header (for advanced layouts)

If you use a layout manager that respects preferred sizes (like BoxLayout or BorderLayout), set the preferred size of the header panel:

upperPanel.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(frame.getWidth(), 36)); // 36px tall

But again, GridLayout, will ignore ths.

frame.setLayout(new BorderLayout());

upperPanel.setBackground(Color.RED);

upperPanel.setLayout(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));

upperPanel.add(titleLabel);

middlePanel.setBackground(Color.YELLOW);

middlePanel.setLayout(new GridLayout(3, 2));

// Add other components...

lowerPanel.setBackground(Color.BLUE);

lowerPanel.setLayout(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));

// Add other components...

frame.add(upperPanel, BorderLayout.NORTH);

frame.add(middlePanel, BorderLayout.CENTER);

frame.add(lowerPanel, BorderLayout.SOUTH);

Final Note

Use BorderLayout for this pattern.
It’s the standard way to have a slim header, flexible content area, and a slim footer in Swing.

Result:

You’ll get a thin red bar at the top, just fitting your "Unit Converter" label, with no wasted vertical space.

Complete Example: Slim Header in Java Swing

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;

public class SlimHeaderExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SwingUtilities.invokeLater(() -> new SlimHeaderExample().createAndShowGUI());
    }

    private void createAndShowGUI() {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(350, 350));
        frame.setLayout(new BorderLayout());
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);

        // --- Header Panel ---
        JPanel headerPanel = new JPanel(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER, 0, 6));
        headerPanel.setBackground(Color.RED);

        JLabel titleLabel = new JLabel("Unit Converter");
        titleLabel.setFont(new Font("Calibri", Font.BOLD, 20));
        titleLabel.setForeground(Color.WHITE);
        headerPanel.add(titleLabel);

        // Optional: force slim height (if you want to be extra sure)
        headerPanel.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(frame.getWidth(), 36)); // 36 pixels tall

        // --- Content Panel ---
        JPanel contentPanel = new JPanel();
        contentPanel.setBackground(Color.YELLOW);
        contentPanel.setLayout(new GridLayout(3, 2, 5, 5));
        // Add your content components here...

        // --- Footer Panel ---
        JPanel footerPanel = new JPanel(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));
        footerPanel.setBackground(Color.BLUE);

        JButton convertButton = new JButton("Convert");
        footerPanel.add(convertButton);

        // --- Add Panels to Frame ---
        frame.add(headerPanel, BorderLayout.NORTH);
        frame.add(contentPanel, BorderLayout.CENTER);
        frame.add(footerPanel, BorderLayout.SOUTH);

        frame.pack();
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }
}

Key Points

  • BorderLayout is used instead of GridLayout.

  • The header (red) is only as tall as needed for the label.

  • You can adjust headerPanel.setPreferredSize() if you want to force a specific height, but usually it’s not needed.

  • The content and footer are unaffected and use the remaining space.

Result:
You get a slim red header bar at the top, just fitting your "Unit Converter" label, with no wasted vertical space.

Let me know if you want this integrated into your full ConverterView class!

As top layout manager. Use it's north, center and south parts and add JPanels to them containing your gui components. Each of these jpanels can have their own layout. Sometimes you can add a component directly to one of those locations.
